[[File:The Land Registry Offices, Lincoln Inn Fields.jpg|thumb|The IGC headquarters is located in [[32 Lincoln's Inn Fields]] on the campus of [[London School of Economics]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theigc.org/about/contact/|title=Contact - IGC|work=IGC|access-date=2018-06-08|language=en-GB}}</ref>]] {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2011}} The '''International Growth Centre''' ('''IGC''') is a research centre based at the [[London School of Economics and Political Science|London School of Economics]] operated in partnership with the [[Blavatnik School of Government]] at the [[University of Oxford]]. The IGC was launched in December 2008 and is funded by the [[Department for International Development]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/website-archive/newsAndMedia/newsArchives/2013/03/IGC.aspx|title=UK invests £51million in International Growth Centre - 03 - 2013 - News archives - News and media - Website archive - Home|last=Editor|first=LSE Web|website=www.lse.ac.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/newsAndMedia/news/archives/2008/IGClaunch.aspx|title=UK launches Growth Centre to tackle global effects of credit crunch|website = lse.ac.uk|publisher=[[London School of Economics and Political Science]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/policies/helping-developing-countries-economies-to-grow|title=Economic growth in developing countries|website = gov.uk|publisher=[[GOV.UK]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bsg.ox.ac.uk/research/research-programmes/international-growth-centre|title=International Growth Centre|date=2017-03-20|work=Blavatnik School of Government|access-date=2018-06-08|language=en}}</ref>
The IGC is led by Professor [[Jonathan Leape]], Executive Director, and Directors Professor [[Robin Burgess]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/economics/people/facultyPages/RobinBurgess.aspx|title=Professor Robin Burgess|website = lse.ac.uk|publisher=[[London School of Economics and Political Science]]}}</ref> and Professor Sir [[Paul Collier]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bsg.ox.ac.uk/people/paul-collier|title=Paul Collier|website =bsg.ox.ac.uk|publisher=[[Blavatnik School of Government]], University of Oxford}}</ref> The IGC Steering Group, which also includes Chang-Tai Hsieh ([[University of Chicago]]),<ref>{{cite web | title = Chang-Tai Hsieh | url = http://www.chicagobooth.edu/faculty/directory/h/chang-tai-hsieh | website = chicagobooth.edu | publisher = [[Booth School of Business|University of Chicago Booth School of Business]] }}</ref> [[Timothy Besley]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/economics/people/facultyPersonalPages/TimBesley.aspx|title=Professor Tim Besley|website = lse.ac.uk|publisher=[[London School of Economics and Political Science]]}}</ref> and [[Anthony Venables]]<ref>{{cite web | last = Venables | first = Anthony | author-link = Anthony Venables | title = Curriculum vitae | url = https://sites.google.com/site/tonyvenables1/tvcvJune14.pdf | format = pdf | publisher = Anthony J Venables }}</ref> provides strategic direction.
The IGC runs 15 country offices in 14 partner states and directs a global network of over 1,000 researchers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theigc.org/countries/|title=Countries | website = theigc.org|publisher=The IGC}}</ref> IGC research is based around four research themes: state, firms, cities, and energy.<ref name="theigc.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.theigc.org/about/structure/|title=Structure | website = theigc.org|publisher=The IGC}}</ref> These research programmes are led by 10 Research Programme Directors. Since its foundation the IGC has supported over 650 research projects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theigc.org/about/|title=About | website = theigc.org|publisher=The IGC}}</ref>
The IGC has also responded to specific government requests for advice in countries such as [[Malawi]], [[Afghanistan]], and [[Sri Lanka]].
IGC country programmes are led by Country Directors working with dedicated Lead Academics, supported by locally based Country Economists. IGC country programme teams are based in the offices of think tanks or government bodies within the relevant country.<ref name="theigc.org"/>
IGC researchers include [[Esther Duflo]], [[Nicholas Bloom]], [[Rachel Glennerster]], [[Lant Pritchett]], [[John Van Reenen (economist)]], [[Nicholas Stern]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/asiaResearchCentre/people/bios/SternNicholas.aspx|title=Professor Lord Nicholas Stern|website = lse.ac.uk|publisher=[[London School of Economics and Political Science]]}}</ref> [[Dean Karlan]], [[Edward Miguel]], and [[Maurice Obstfeld]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theigc.org/people/researchers-directory/|title=Researchers directory | website = theigc.org|publisher=The IGC}}</ref>
==Country programmes==
For each partner country, the IGC supports a team of resident economists who respond to specific policy demands on issues of economic growth. This covers applied economic analysis, long-term research and policy engagement activities, as well as rapid responses to pressing policy questions.
The IGC [[Bangladesh]] programme was established in 2009. It is currently hosted in the [[BRAC University]] Institute of Governance and Development. The programme focuses on five areas of research: i) state effectiveness ii) firm capabilities iii) [[food security]] iv) [[infrastructure]] development, and v) sustainable [[urbanisation]] in Bangladesh. Professor [[Mushfiq Mobarak]] ([[Yale University]] and Professor Fahad Khalil ([[University of Washington]]) serve as Lead Academics for IGC Bangladesh. In 2014, IGC country researcher and former caretaker government adviser, Wahiduddin Mahmud addressed an IGC co-hosted conference at BRAC University on the issue of dysfunctional governance in Bangladesh.<ref>{{cite news | last = FE Report | title = Dysfunctional governance remains serious problem | url = http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/2014/12/12/70638 | work = [[The Financial Express (Bangladesh)|The Financial Express]] | location = Bangladesh | date = 12 December 2014 }}</ref>
The IGC [[Ethiopia]] programme was established in 2010, in partnership with the Ethiopian Development Research Institute. IGC Ethiopia focuses on the following research areas: [[industrial development]], [[urbanisation]], developing [[agriculture]], [[youth unemployment]], and state effectiveness. In 2014 IGC Ethiopia jointly sponsored a small grants scheme for junior researchers with the Ethiopian Economics Association. In 2012, a study of youth unemployment in Ethiopia was conducted by the IGC which found that whilst unemployment in urban areas remains widespread, it has declined greatly since 1999. The same study also found that women have not benefited as much as men from reductions in unemployment.<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Broussar | first1 = Nzinga H. | last2 = Tekleselassie | first2 = Tsegay Gebrekidan | title = Youth unemployment: Ethiopia country study | url = http://www.theigc.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/09/Broussar-Tekleselassie-2012-Working-Paper.pdf | format = pdf | id = 12/0592 | date = August 2012 |publisher=The IGC }}</ref>
The IGC [[Ghana]] programme was initiated in 2009. It is led by Dr. Nii Sowa (Country Director), Dr. Sam Mensah (Co-Country Director), and Lead Academic and Professor [[Christopher Udry]] ([[Yale University]]). IGC Ghana has funded research in areas such as [[macroeconomic]] stability, [[agricultural productivity]], [[private sector development]], [[education]] and skills acquisition and [[natural resource management]]. IGC Ghana is based at the Institute of Statistical, Social and Economic Research at the [[University of Ghana]]. The IGC, in partnership with the Ministry of Finance of Ghana and the Bank of Ghana, organized the Africa Growth Forum 2014, which brought together policymakers, academics, and researchers to discuss issues relating to the Ghanaian economy.<ref>{{cite news | last = cajnews Africa|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201406181407.html|title=Ghana: budget deficits hurt Ghana's reputation|work=[[AllAfrica.com]] | publisher = AllAfrica Global Media | date = 17 June 2014 }}</ref>
The IGC [[Bihar]] programme was initiated in 2009. It is hosted by the [[Asian Development Research Institute]] in [[Patna]], [[India]]. IGC Bihar has funded research on [[literacy]], [[vocational training]], [[economic policy]], and [[public finance]]. In 2014, the organization organised the Bihar Growth Conference which was attended by the Chief Minister of Bihar, [[Jitan Ram Manjhi]], who has also attended the IGC Growth Week 2014 in London.<ref>{{cite news | last = TNN|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/Help-shape-growth-of-Bihar-CM/articleshow/38708058.cms|title=Help shape growth of Bihar: CM|work=[[The Times of India]]|publisher = [[The Times Group]]| date = 20 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Raj | first = Anand |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1140921/jsp/frontpage/story_18855493.jsp|title=UK-bound to tap investors|work=[[The Telegraph (Calcutta)|The Telegraph]] | location = Calcutta, India | publisher = ABP Group | date = 21 September 2014}}</ref>
The IGC [[India]] Central programme was launched in April 2010. The team is led by Dr. Pronab Sen (Country Director), Professor Dilip Mookherjee (Lead Academic) and Professor [[Eswar Prasad]] (Lead Academic). It is based within the [[Indian Statistical Institute]] in [[Delhi]], [[India]]. the IGC India Central team also manages 'Ideas for India', a web-based economic and policy blog.<ref>{{cite web | title = Home page |url=http://ideasforindia.in/Default.aspx | website = ideasforindia.in |publisher=Ideas for India}}</ref> In 2013, the IGC South Asia Growth Conference was held in Delhi which addressed schooling, public sector and programme design, macroeconomics and finance, firms and investmennt, and health.<ref>{{cite web | last = South Asia @ LSE | title = IGC perspectives on growth in India (blog) | url = http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/indiaatlse/2013/07/26/igc-perspectives-on-growth-in-india/ | website = blogs.lse.ac.uk | publisher = [[London School of Economics]] | date = 26 July 2013 }}</ref>
The IGC [[Liberia]] programme focuses on four themes: strengthening state capabilities, [[natural resource management]], [[macroeconomic]] management, and [[urbanisation]]. Following initial engagement in 2011 and consultations with Liberian stakeholders in 2012, IGC officially established its Liberia office in February 2013, based in the Ministry of State Without Portfolio. Liberia's Minister for Commerce and Industry, [[Axel Addy|Axel M. Addy]], spoke as part of IGC Growth Week 2014 in London.<ref>{{cite news|last =Ridley |first = Louise|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/09/26/liberia-ebola-epidemic-economy-jobs-schools_n_5887880.html|title=Ghost nation: how Ebola is threatening daily life in Liberia with 'chaos and collapse'|date=26 September 2014|work=[[The Huffington Post]] | location = UK}}</ref>
The IGC [[Mozambique]] programme was established in October 2010. IGC Mozambique’s research agenda has developed around three broad themes: [[private sector development]], state effectiveness, and the development of [[agriculture]]. IGC Mozambique is directed by its two Lead Academics Dr Sandra Sequeira ([[London School of Economics and Political Science]]) and Pedro Vicente ([[Nova School of Business and Economics]]). The IGC has organized several events in Mozambique, including a workshop on management practices in the manufacturing sector, and a forum on economic growth.<ref>{{cite news|last=Meignen|first=Eva|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201412152711.html|title=Mozambique: management practices in the manufacturing sector|work=[[AllAfrica.com]] | publisher = AllAfrica Global Media | date = 3 December 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Meignen|first=Eva |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201406190407.html |title= Mozambique: economic growth forum gathered top personalities in Maputo |work=[[AllAfrica.com]] | publisher = AllAfrica Global Media | date = 18 June 2014 }}</ref>
The IGC [[Myanmar]] programme began in 2012. It operates in partnership with Myanmar Development Resource Institute – Centre for Economic and Social Development (MDRI-CESD) and has researched subjects including [[labour regulation]] and [[natural resource management]]. The organization has also projected revenue receipts for the Internal Revenue Department in Myanmar with its partners.<ref>{{cite news | title = IRD expects Ks 329 bn revenue from oil and gas sector | url = http://mmbusinessnews.blogspot.co.uk/2014/07/ird-expects-ks-329-bn-revenue-from-oil.html | work = Elevenmyanmar.com | publisher = [[Eleven Media Group]] via mmbusinessnews.blogspot | location = [[Myanmar]] | date = 22 June 2014 }}</ref>
The IGC [[Pakistan]] programme was initiated in 2010. it is based within the [[Lahore University of Management Sciences]] and is guided by Dr. Ijaz Nabi (Country Director), Dr. Naved Hamid (Resident Director), Dr. Ali Cheema (Lead Academic) and Dr. Asim Khwaja (Lead Academic). The programme currently focuses on five policy areas for growth – [[macroeconomic]] management, state capabilities, firm capabilities, [[urbanisation]] and [[energy]]. It is currently working closely with the governments of [[Punjab, Pakistan]] and [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] on medium-term economic planning. Research funded by the IGC into the Pakistan football-making industry found that despite supplying firms with cost-cutting technology, take-up rates of the new technology were low due to misaligned incentives between workers and the company.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://finchannel.com/old/Main_News/B_Schools/130976_Pakistan's_football_factories_score_goal_for_innovation/|title=Pakistan's football factories score goal for innovation|last=News Editor| work =[[The Financial]] |publisher= Intelligence Group |date=30 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last = Columbia University | title = Economists use soccer balls to study the adoption of innovative technology | url = http://phys.org/news/2014-06-economists-soccer-balls-technology.html | work = [[Phys.org]] | publisher = Omicron Technology Ltd | date = 25 June 2014 }}</ref> The organization has also funded research into low tax collection in Punjab, and successfully instituted a 'pay for performance' scheme in Punjab that raised significant tax revenue.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.brecorder.com/taxation/181:pakistan/1144073:incentives-could-raise-amount-of-tax-collection-new-igc-film/|title=Incentives could raise amount of tax collection: new IGC film|last=Recorder Report|work=[[Business Recorder]]|publisher=[[Business Recorder Group]]|date=21 January 2015}}</ref>
The IGC [[Rwanda]] programme began operations in November 2010, at the request of President [[Paul Kagame]]. It operates under a Memorandum of Understanding with the [[Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning (Rwanda)]] which requires that it “produce demand-driven research outputs that strengthen the evidence base for policy-making relevant to Rwanda’s long-run growth”, with a focus on research and analysis under four main thematic areas: [[agriculture]], [[infrastructure]], [[macroeconomic policy]] and [[finance]], and [[trade]] and [[industry]]. The IGC participated in a Rwanda Research Roundtable in 2014 as part of its partnership with the Rwandan government.<ref>{{cite news | last = IGIHE Reporter | title= Rwanda advised to use evidences in formulating education policy |url= http://en.igihe.com/news/rwanda-advised-to-use-evidences-in-formulating.html |work=IGIHE |publisher=IGIHE Ltd | date = 28 October 2014}}</ref> A joint NAEB-IGC study on the Rwandan coffee sector found that Rwandan export revenues are affected by coffee washing stations operating below capacity, with the majority of the washing stations lacking funding.<ref>{{cite news | last = Tumwebaze | first = Peterson |url=http://www.newtimes.co.rw/section/article/2015-02-25/186325/|title=Half of coffee washing stations operate below capacity- report |work=[[The New Times (Rwanda)|The New Times]]| location = Rwanda | date = 25 February 2015 }}</ref>
The IGC [[Sierra Leone]] programme is based at the Centre of Policy Studies at the [[University of Sierra Leone]]. Its main areas of research are state capabilities, [[agriculture]], and [[governance]]. Research conducted by the IGC has found that the number of rice traders in some Ebola-hit areas of Sierra Leone has fallen by nearly 70% between 2012 and late 2014. The economic consequences of Ebola in Sierra Leone are continuing to be monitored by the IGC.<ref>{{cite web|last = Staff writer|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-30088818|title=Ebola outbreak: latest news in 15 seconds|work=[[BBC News]] | publisher = [[BBC]] |date= 17 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last= Glennerster |first= Rachel |url=http://theconversation.com/how-to-plan-for-a-post-ebola-west-africa-33433|title=How to plan for a post-Ebola West Africa |work=[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] | publisher = The Conversation Trust |date=7 November 2014}}</ref>
The IGC [[South Sudan]] programme opened in August 2012. The programme is structured around three main pillars: responding to [[crisis]], [[natural resource management]], and addressing [[Remote and isolated community|isolation]], [[Agricultural diversification|diversification]], and [[job creation]]. The organization has published several studies regarding the oil sector in South Sudan.<ref>{{cite web |title=Managing oil savings |url=http://www.theigc.org/project/managing-oil-savings/ | website = theigc.org |publisher=The IGC}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theigc.org/project/institutions-and-the-oil-sector-in-south-sudan/|title=Institutions and the oil sector in South Sudan | website = theigc.org |publisher=The IGC}}</ref>
The IGC [[Tanzania]] programme was established in 2008 – the first in-country programme of the IGC. The Tanzania programme is headed by Country Director Dr. John Page ([[Brookings Institution]]), Lead Academic Professor Chris Adam ([[University of Oxford]]) and Senior Country Research and Policy Fellow Dr. Pantaleo Kessy ([[Bank of Tanzania]]). IGC Tanzania's office is hosted by the [[Bank of Tanzania]], and has so far focused on researching [[poverty reduction]], structural transformation, preparation for [[monetary union]], [[inflation]] and fiscal strategy. Other areas of research include firm capabilities, [[urbanisation]], and [[energy]]. Professor John Sutton, an IGC researcher, delivered the Gilman Rutihinda Memorial Lecture at the Bank of Tanzania and urged the country to integrate local firms into gas multinational supply chains.<ref>{{cite news | last = Kiishweko | first = Orton |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201406120207.html|title=Tanzania: Forum demands for more local content in gas industry |work=[[AllAfrica.com]] | publisher = AllAfrica Global Media | date = 12 June 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theigc.org/event/public-lecture-local-content-and-tanzanias-industrial-development-professor-john-sutton/|title=Public lecture: Local content and Tanzania’s industrial development (Professor John Sutton) | website = theigc.org |publisher=The IGC}}</ref>
The IGC [[Uganda]] programme has been hosted at the [[Bank of Uganda]] since it opened in 2012. Its priority areas include [[natural resource management]] and [[monetary policy]], the [[regional integration]] process, raising [[income]] and [[inclusive growth]]. IGC Uganda research has included analysis of integration of economic activity within the [[East African Community]], the evolution of [[public expenditure]] priorities in light of [[natural resource]] revenues, and the options and strategies for financing fiscal deficits within the country. IGC research showed that eight out of ten Rwandan farmers in the study are not willing to adopt fertilisers as they are perceived as low quality.<ref>{{cite news | last = Barungi | first = Mildred |title=Substandard inputs are hindering technology adoption |url=http://www.observer.ug/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=35571 |work =[[The Observer (Uganda)|The Observer]]|publisher=Observer Media Ltd | location = Uganda | date = 18 December 2014 }}</ref>
The IGC [[Zambia]] programme started in 2010. It established its country office in 2011, located at the Zambian Institute for Policy Analysis and Research (ZIPAR). The IGC has collaborated with the Zambian Ministry of Health to test recruitment strategies for health workers in rural areas, which have now been implemented and scaled up by the Zambian government.<ref>{{cite news | last = The Financial | title = Improving the recruitment of community health workers in Zambia |url= http://finchannel.com/index.php/world/georgian-news/health-beauty/item/37803- | work =[[The Financial]] |publisher= Intelligence Group |date= 16 May 2014 }}</ref> The IGC has also engaged with the Zambia Revenue Authority.<ref>{{cite news | last = Online user | title = ZRA collects K27m in taxes | url = https://www.daily-mail.co.zm/?p=18311 | work = [[Zambia Daily Mail]] | publisher = [[Government of Zambia]] | date = 26 January 2015 }}</ref>
==Research programmes==
IGC research is focused within four research themes: state, firms, [[cities]], and [[energy]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.theigc.org/research-themes/ |title= Research themes | website = theigc.org |publisher=The IGC }}</ref>
The IGC '''state''' research programme looks at the role of the public sector in economic development. Within the State research theme, the IGC has worked on 364 projects and organised 33 events.<ref name="theigc.org1">{{cite web | url = http://www.theigc.org/publication/our-work/ | title = Our work | website = theigc.org |publisher=The IGC }}</ref> The state research programme is headed by Professor [[Oriana Bandiera]] ([[London School of Economics and Political Science]]), Professor Henrik Kleven ([[London School of Economics and Political Science]]), Professor Eliana La Ferrera ([[Bocconi University]]), and Professor Gerard Padro i Miquel ([[London School of Economics and Political Science]]).
One IGC state project run by [[Raj Chetty]] ([[Harvard University]]), Nasiruddin Ahmed ([[BRAC University]]), Ghulam Hossain (Chairman of the Pakistani [[National Board of Revenue]]), Ahmed Mushfiq Mobarak ([[Yale University]]), Aminur Rahman ([[University of Virginia]]), and Monica Singhal ([[Harvard University]]) looked at how social recognition can be used to increase value-added tax revenue in Pakistan.<ref name="mushfiqmobarak">{{cite web | last = Mobarak | first = Mushfiq |title=Tax compliance and social acclaim |url=http://www.livemint.com/Opinion/XwvGdsQDgePOLD6SFGXSTI/Tax-compliance-and-social-acclaim.html |work= [[Mint (newspaper)|Mint]] | publisher = [[HT Media]] | location = India | date = 15 September 2014 }}</ref> The researchers sent letters to inform firms that their tax compliance behaviour would be shared with other firms in their cluster in a subsequent letter. They hypothesised that this intervention may spur voluntary tax compliance by allowing firms to be recognised by their neighbours and peers. They found that in areas of low tax compliance, where less than 15% of firms paid any VAT the previous year (in 2012), the peer recognition treatment had no significant effect on tax payment rates. However, in areas where at least 15% of firms had paid VAT in 2012, firms who received the peer recognition treatment were 3.4 percentage points more likely to make a payment in the post-intervention period<ref name="mushfiqmobarak"/>
The IGC '''firms''' research programme seeks to understand the forces that determine the productivity of firms. Within the Firms research theme, the IGC has worked on 293 projects and organised 25 events.<ref name="theigc.org1"/> The IGC’s Firms research programme is headed by Professor [[Nicholas Bloom]] ([[Stanford University]]), Professor Tavneet Suri ([[MIT Sloan School of Management]]), Professor Christopher Udry ([[Yale University]]), Professor Eric Verhoogen ([[Columbia University]]), Dr Greg Fischer ([[London School of Economics and Political Science]]), Professor Imran Rasul ([[University College London]]), Professor Andres Rodriguez-Clare ([[University of California, Berkeley]]), and Professor Christopher Woodruff ([[University of Warwick]]).<ref name="theigc.org1"/>
An IGC firms project in [[Sialkot]], [[Pakistan]], one of the world’s top producers of footballs, found that employees in factories producing footballs resisted a new technology that limited waste and improved efficiency.<ref>{{cite news | last = Cronin | first = Brenda | title = How automation fell flat in the world’s soccer-ball capital |url= https://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2014/04/28/how-automation-fell-flat-in-the-worlds-soccer-ball-capital/ |work= [[The Wall Street Journal]] | publisher = [[News Corp]] | date = 28 April 2014 }}</ref> Researchers found a new way to cut the footballs' pentagon panels from sheets of [[rexine]], and they provided football manufacturers with a new cutting pattern and new cutting tools to implement the new design.<ref name="newseditor">{{cite news |last = News Editor | url= http://finchannel.com/old/Main_News/B_Schools/130976_Pakistan%27s_football_factories_score_goal_for_innovation/|title= Pakistan's football factories score goal for innovation | work =[[The Financial]] |publisher= Intelligence Group | date = 30 May 2014 }}</ref> While one of the largest companies in the city quickly adopted the new technology for almost all its production, few others followed suit. Based on further investigation, the researchers conjectured that take-up was slow because employees were resisting the new technology. Cutters were paid per piece, with no incentive to reduce waste, and were concerned that the new die would slow them down and reduce their incomes.<ref name="newseditor"/>
The IGC '''[[cities]]''' research programme explores the challenges of urbanisation in the developing world and the potential of cities to act as drivers of [[economic growth]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Bale | first = Jo |title=From cities to states |url= http://www.lse.ac.uk/alumni/LSEConnect/articlesSummer2014/fromCitiesToStates.aspx | website = lse.ac.uk | publisher = [[London School of Economics]] | date = Summer 2014 | quote = Jonathan Leape, new director of the International Growth Centre at LSE, explains the four research themes that will help power development in 15 countries across the world. }}</ref> The IGC’s cities research programme is led by [[Edward Glaeser]] ([[Harvard University]]) and Gharad Bryan ([[London School of Economics and Political Science]]).<ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.hks.harvard.edu/centers/rappaport/events-and-news/audio-and-video-clips/developing-world-cities-promise-and-challenge|title=Developing world cities: promise and challenge | website = hks.harvard.edu |publisher= [[Harvard Kennedy School]]}}</ref> 45 projects and nine events have been funded through the IGC cities programme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theigc.org/research-themes/cities/|title=Cities | website = theigc.org |publisher=The IGC }}</ref>
The IGC '''[[energy]]''' research programme analyses the role that energy plays in shaping the growth of developing countries. Within the Energy research theme, the IGC has worked on 55 projects and organised four events.<ref name="theigc.org1"/> The energy programme is headed by Professor [[Michael Greenstone]] ([[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]) and Professor Nicholas Ryan ([[Yale University]]).<ref name="theigc.org1"/>
==Events==
The IGC holds a number of [http://www.theigc.org/events/ events] throughout the year with the purpose of discussing a wide range of economic growth-related issues, sharing the findings of its research, and stimulating policy debates within the IGC’s four thematic focus areas: cities, energy, state effectiveness, and firms.
IGC events focus on combining research and policy and feature speakers from IGC‘s network of researchers and policymakers from Africa and South Asia.
The IGC’s flagship events are “Growth Week”,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2016/jun/09/cut-poverty-africa-china-economic-boom-self-interest-development|title=Will giving fat cats some of the cream help to cut poverty?|date=2016-06-09|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.publicfinanceinternational.org/news/2016/06/city-growth-asia-and-africa-examined-lse-conference|title=City growth in Asia and Africa examined at LSE conference {{!}} Public Finance|website=www.publicfinanceinternational.org|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref> its annual conference in London, and a series of smaller regional and thematic conferences held in the UK, Africa,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.tralac.org/news/article/7998-africa-rising-the-new-growth-agenda.html|title=Africa rising: The new growth agenda|last=|first=|date=|website=www.tralac.org|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref> and South Asia with the aim of forging collaborations between policymakers and academics.
In addition, a number of in-country research dissemination and policy events and workshops are held every year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/IGC-conference-Governor-calls-for-distributive-justice/articleshow/53244715.cms|title=IGC conference: Governor calls for 'distributive justice' - Times of India|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://novafrica.org/novafrica-conference-innovations-and-challenges-in-financial-development-in-mozambique/?lang=pt-pt|title=NOVAFRICA » Conferência NOVAFRICA sobre o Desenvolvimento Financeiro em Moçambique – Inovação e Desafios|website=novafrica.org|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref> The IGC also holds a number of public lectures<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://kashmirlinklondon.co.uk/?p=6955|title=World should apply uniform standards on all terrorist incidents|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/global-development-professionals-network/2015/dec/09/how-to-transform-the-lives-of-ultra-poor-women-new-evidence-from-brac-in-bangladesh|title=How to transform the lives of ultra-poor women: new evidence from Brac in Bangladesh|last=Green|first=Duncan|date=2015-12-09|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=2016-08-30}}</ref> at the [[London School of Economics|London School of Economics and Political Science]].

'''Jose de Segovia''' ([[Madrid]], 1964) is a Spanish teacher, journalist & theologian.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gabino Fernández Campos|title=''Encyclopedia of Spanish Protestantism'' |publisher=Protestantes.net |url=http://www.protestantes.net/enciclopedia.asp?id=637 |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> He studied journalism at [[Universidad Complutense]] ([[Madrid]]),<ref>{{cite web |title=''Interview: Introducing Jose De Segovia'' |publisher=Reformation21.org |url=http://www.reformation21.org/blog/2015/03/introducing-jose-de-segovia.php |author=Paul Levy |date=2015-03-13 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> theology at [[Protestant Theological University|University of Kampen]] ([[Netherlands]]) and Bible at The School of Biblical Studies [[Welwyn]] ([[England]]), where he became interested in the work of preacher [[Martyn Lloyd-Jones]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Xavier Memba |url=https://predicalia.wordpress.com/2009/04/02/entrevista-a-jose-de-segovia/ |language=es|title=''Interview: José de Segovia'' |publisher=Predicalia.wordpress.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> de Segovia is currently leading active student groups such as European Mission Fellowship,<ref>{{cite web|author=Emma Bunting |url=http://europeanmission.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=122:european-huddle&catid=44&Itemid=567 |title=''Introducing José de Segovia by European Missionary Fellowship'' |publisher=Europeanmission.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> [[International Fellowship of Evangelical Students]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Francisco Mira |url=http://www.publicacionesandamio.com/products-page/jose-de-segovia/ |language=es|title=''Introducing José de Segovia by Andamio'' |publisher=Publicacionesandamio.com |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> and Unión Bíblica.<ref>{{cite web|author=David Vergara |url=http://edificacioncristiana.com/actualidad/articulo1.php |title=''Edificación Cristiana'' |publisher=Edificacioncristiana.com |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> He was also President of the Theological Commission on Spanish Evangelical Alliance between 2001 and 2015<ref>{{cite web|author=Evangelina Sierra Bernardino | url=http://www.aeesp.net/pdf/conocenos/memoriaanual/2012/AEE_MEMORIA_2012.pdf |title=''Spanish Evangelical Alliance Dossier, 2012'' |publisher=Aeesp.net |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> and representative of the [[World Evangelical Alliance]] in theological dialogue with the [[Holy See|Vatican]].<ref>{{cite web|author=WEA|title=''Growing Christian Solidarity between Catholics and Evangelicals'' |url=http://www.worldea.org/news/3704/Growing-Christian-Solidarity-between-Catholics-and-Evangelicals |publisher=Worldea.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Joel Forster |title=''Spanish Evangelical Alliance 2015 Meeting'' |publisher=Evangelicalfocus.com|url=http://evangelicalfocus.com/europe/386/A_solid_evangelical_identity_knows_how_to_listen_discourse_and_contend_for_the_faith |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
==Teaching== de Segovia has taught religious studies at the following schools.
* The School of Biblical Studies [[Welwyn]], [[England]] <ref>{{cite web|author=EMF|url=http://europeanmission.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=33 |title=''European Missionary Fellowship'' |publisher=Europeanmission.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * Facultad Internacional de Teología [[Castelldefels]], [[Spain]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Pedro Sanjaime|url=http://www.ibste.org/profesorado.html |title=''Profesorado'' |publisher=IBSTE |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * Centro Evangélico de Estudios Bíblicos [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Pedro Puigvert|url=http://www.ceeb.org.es/cd_00.html |title=''Cuerpo docente'' |publisher=Ceeb.org.es |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * Facultad de Teología Protestante [[Madrid]], [[Spain]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Roberto Velert|url=http://www.ftuebe.es/depastoral.html |title=''Facultad Protestante de Teología UEBE'' |publisher=Ftuebe.es |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
== Books == Spanish author and historian [[Cesar Vidal Manzanares]] wrote that "José de Segovia Barrón write theological opinions and culture reviews in the highest professional level, lighting the topics because of its own particular deep perception of life. Reading often his articles it's a pleasure to me, because his own intellectual approach confirms that the Christian thinking does not stunt the brain but, if it's properly used, mind is actually reinforce and encouraged".<ref>{{cite web|author=Cesar Vidal Manzanares |url=http://www.entrelineas.org/contacto.asp |title=''Entrelíneas: Revista de Arte y Fe'' |language=es|publisher=Entrelineas.org |date=2015-06-27 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
* ''Bob Dylan''. (Andamio, 1985) * ''El protestantismo en España: Pasado, presente y futuro'' (CEM/AMECAN, 1997) * ''Guerra Espiritual: Una reflexión Crítica'' (AEE. Barcelona, 1988) * ''Una fe para el tercer milenio (Peregrino'' Moral de Calatrava, 2002) * ''Entrelíneas: Arte y Fe'' (Consejo Evangélico de Madrid, 2003) Foreword by [[Cesar Vidal Manzanares]] * ''Ocultismo'' (Andamio. Barcelona, 2004) * ''El príncipe Caspian y la fe de C. S. Lewis'' (Andamio, 2008) * ''Huellas del cristianismo en el cine'' (Consejo Evangélico de Madrid, 2010) * ''El asombro del perdón'' (Andamio, 2010) * ''Center Church Europe'' (Wijnen, Uitgeverij Van, 2014) Co-Author with [[Tim Keller (pastor)]] * ''Evangelio según San Lucas para la Unión Bíblica'' (CLIE, 2016)
== Magazines and digital publications == During the years de Segovia spent at the University (1983-1988) he became interested in Christian thinkers like [[C.S. Lewis]], [[Francis Schaeffer]] and [[José Grau Balcells]], a Spanish writer that he later call his "spiritual father".<ref>{{cite web|author=José de Segovia Barrón |url=http://www.entrelineas.org/leer.asp?a=jose-grau-soli-deo-gloria |language=es|title=''José Grau: Soli Deu Gloria'' |publisher=Entrelineas.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> Historian Gabino Fernández Campos wrote that during these early years, de Segovia was collaborating for Spanish & Dutch magazines like ''Aura'', ''Panorama Evangélico'', ''Adelante'', ''Cuadernos Reforma'', ''Nederlands Dagblad'' or ''Internieuws''.<ref>{{cite web|author=Gabino Fernández Campos |url=http://www.protestantes.net/enciclopedia.asp?id=637 |language=es|title=''Enciclopedia del Centro de Estudios de la Reforma'' |publisher=Protestantes.net |date=2015-06-27 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
The following are de Segovia's more popular publications: * ''Entrelíneas''. Printed fanzine including [[Cesar Vidal Manzanares]] or Luís Alfredo Díaz-Britos. Madrid, 1985.<ref>{{cite web|author=Melisa Panduro Ugaz |url=https://elspleendelosmonos.wordpress.com/2015/05/22/entrevista-a-jose-de-segovia/ |language=es|title=''En el mundo del periodismo de cultura sobran opiniones''. Entrevista a José de Segovia | elspleendelosmonos |publisher=Blog: El Spleen de los monos |date=2015-05-22 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * '"Gospel Club". ''Radio Popular'', 1985 and 1987. * ''Kalos''. Magazine including Jonathan Gelabert. Granollers, 1987. * ''Cultura Pop''. [[RNE Radio 3]], 1987.<ref>{{cite web|author=José Pablo Fernández |url=http://www.protestantes.net/Biblio/Actas/EHP/EHP20e.htm |title=''Encuentro de Historiadores'' |publisher=Protestantes.net |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * Entrelíneas. Online magazine including more than 1000 reviews & podcast since 2002.<ref>{{cite web|author=José de Segovia Barrón |url=http://www.entrelineas.org |title=''Entrelíneas: Revista de Arte y Fe'' |publisher=Entrelineas.org |language=es|date=2015-06-27 |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * ''Radio Encuentro'', including weekly radio interviews since 2010.<ref>{{cite web|author=Sebastián Feliu|url=http://www.radioencuentro.net/index.php/entre-lineas |title=''Entrelíneas'' |publisher=Radio Encuentro |language=es|date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> * ''Evangelical Focus'', including weekly culture reviews since 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author=José de Segovia Barrón |url=http://evangelicalfocus.com/l/blogs/709/Between_the_Lines |title=''Between the Lines'' |publisher=Evangelical Focus |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref>
== Personal life == de Segovia is pastor at Reformed Church in Madrid.<ref>{{cite web|author=José Hutter |url=http://iglesiareformadamadrid.org/?q=about/staff/jos%C3%A9-de-segovia-barr%C3%B3n |title=''Staff Directory | Iglesia Reformada de Madrid'' |language=es|publisher=Iglesiareformadamadrid.org |date= |accessdate=2015-07-04}}</ref> He and his wife Anna have four children.
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{Refimprove|date=May 2007}} '''Legislation''' (or "[[statutory law]]") is law which has been [[promulgation|promulgated]] (or "[[enactment of a bill|enacted]]") by a [[legislature]] or other [[Government|governing body]] or the process of making it.<ref>See Article 289(3) of the [[Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union]]</ref> Before an item of legislation becomes law it may be known as a [[bill (proposed law)|bill]], and may be broadly referred to as "legislation", while it remains under consideration to distinguish it from other business. Legislation can have many purposes: to regulate, to authorize, to outlaw, to provide (funds), to sanction, to grant, to declare or to restrict. It may be contrasted with a non-legislative act which is adopted by an [[Executive (government)|executive]] or administrative body under the authority of a legislative act or for implementing a legislative act.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Is the European Legislator after Lisbon a real Legislature? |author=Wim Voermans |journal=Legislacao Cadernos de Ciencia de Legislacao |volume=50 |pages=391–413 [402] |date=December 2009 |quote=Within the category of legal acts provided for by the TFEU, a distinction is made between legislative acts and non-legislative acts. Legislative acts are decisions adopted under the ordinary or special legislative procedure (Article 289(3) of the TFEU) and non-legislative acts are decisions that are adopted pursuant to delegation or for the purpose of implementing a legislative act (Articles 35 See Article 288 of the TFEU, last 290 and 291 of the TFEU)}}</ref>
Under the [[Westminster system]], an item of primary legislation is known as an [[Act of Parliament]] after enactment.
Legislation is usually proposed by a member of the legislature (e.g. a member of Congress or Parliament), or by the executive, whereupon it is debated by members of the legislature and is often amended before [[passage (legislature)|passage]]. Most large legislatures enact only a small fraction of the bills proposed in a given [[Session (parliamentary procedure)|session]].<ref>[https://www.senate.gov/pagelayout/reference/two_column_table/Resumes.htm Senate.gov]</ref> Whether a given bill will be proposed and is generally a matter of the legislative priorities of government.
Legislation is regarded as one of the three main functions of government, which are often distinguished under the doctrine of the [[separation of powers]]. Those who have the formal power to ''create'' legislation are known as [[legislator]]s; a [[judiciary|judicial branch]] of government will have the formal power to ''interpret'' legislation (see [[statutory interpretation]]); the [[executive branch]] of government can act only within the powers and limits set by the law.
== Latest revision == The function and procedures are primarily the responsibility of the legislature. However, there are situations where legislation is made by other bodies or means, such as when [[constitutional law]] or [[secondary legislation]] is enacted. Such other forms of law-making include [[referendum]]s, [[Order in Council|orders in council]] or [[regulations]]. The term ''legislation'' is sometimes used to include these situations, or the term ''[[primary legislation]]'' may be used to exclude these other forms.
==Dead letter== {{Expand section|date=September 2016}} The phrase "dead letter" refers to legislation that has not been revoked, but that has become inapplicable or obsolete or is no longer enforced.<ref>[https://definitions.uslegal.com/d/dead-letter Dead Letter]</ref>
==See also== * [[Statutory law]] * [[Delegated legislation]] * [[Legislative bill]] * [[Primary legislation]] * [[Special legislation]]

[[File:Classic alphabet chart at coloring-pages-for-kids-boys-dotcom.svg|thumb|right|[[English alphabet]]. [[Letter (alphabet)|Letters]] form the basis for many [[languages]], including English]]
'''Linguistic Intelligence''' is a part of [[Howard Gardner]]'s [[Theory of multiple intelligences|multiple intelligence theory]] that deals with individuals' ability to understand both [[Spoken language|spoken]] and [[written language]], as well as their ability to speak and write themselves. In a practical sense, linguistic intelligence is the extent to which an individual can use [[language]], both written and verbal, to achieve goals.<ref name="FM 2012">{{cite journal|last=Fernandez-Martinez|first=Fernando|author2=Kseniya Zablotskaya |author3=Wolfgang Minker |title=Text categorization methods for automatic estimation of verbal intelligence|journal=Expert Systems with Applications|date=Aug 2012|volume=39|issue=10|pages=9807–9820|doi=10.1016/j.eswa.2012.02.173}}</ref> In addition to this, high linguistic intelligence has been linked to improved [[problem solving]], as well as to increased [[Abstraction|abstract reasoning]].<ref name="Luwel 2013">{{cite journal|last=Luwel|first=Koen|author2=Ageliki Foustana |author3=Patrick Onghena |author4=Lieven Verschaffel |title=The role of verbal and performance intelligence in children's strategy selection and execution|journal=Learning and Individual Differences|date=Apr 2013|volume=24|pages=134–138|doi=10.1016/j.lindif.2013.01.010}}</ref>
In many cases, only the verbal aspects are taken into consideration. This is usually referred to as verbal intelligence or verbal fluency, and is commonly a reflection of an individual's overall linguistic intelligence.
==Physiologic and functional overview== In order to understand linguistic intelligence, it is important to understand the [[Mechanism (biology)|mechanisms]] that control speech and language. These mechanisms can be broken down into four major groups: [[speech|speech generation]] (talking), [[Hearing|speech comprehension]] (hearing), [[Writing|writing generation]] (writing), and [[Reading (process)|writing comprehension]] (reading).
===Spoken language===
====Generation==== {{Main|Speech}} [[File:Inferior frontal gyrus.png|thumb|left|[[Inferior frontal gyrus]]; a major part of the [[inferior frontal cortex]]]] Speech production is process by which a thought in the brain is converted into an understandable auditory form.<ref name="Bohland 2010">{{cite journal|last=Bohland|first=Jason|author2=Daniel Bullock |author3=Frank Guenther |title=Neural Representations and Mechanisms for the Performance of Simple Speech Sequences|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|date=Jul 2010|volume=22|issue=7|pages=1504–1529|doi=10.1162/jocn.2009.21306|pmid=19583476|pmc=2937837}}</ref><ref name="Dan 2013">{{cite journal|last=Dan|first=Haruka |author2=Sano, Kyutoku |author3=Oguro, Yokota |author4=Tsuzuki, Watanabe|title=Language-specific cortical activation patterns for verbal fluency tasks in Japanese as assessed by multichannel functional near-infrared spectroscopy|journal=Brain and Language|date=Aug 2013|volume=126|issue=2|pages=208–216|doi=10.1016/j.bandl.2013.05.007}}</ref><ref name="Rodd 2005">{{cite journal|last=Rodd|first=J.M. |author2=M.H. Davis |author3=I.S. Johnsrude|title=The neural mechanisms of speech comprehension: fMRI studies of semantic ambiguity|journal=Cerebral Cortex|date=Aug 2005|volume=15|issue=8|pages=1261–1269|doi=10.1093/cercor/bhi009|pmid=15635062}}</ref> This is a multistage mechanism that involves many different areas of the brain. The first stage is planning, where the brain constructs words and sentences that turn the thought into an understandable form.<ref name="Bohland 2010" /> This occurs primarily in the [[inferior frontal cortex]], specifically in an area known as [[Broca's area]].<ref name="Dan 2013" /><ref name="Rodd 2005" /><ref name="Konrad 2012">{{cite journal|last=Konrad|first=Andreas|author2=Goran Vucurevic |author3=Francesco Musso |author4=Georg Winterer |title=VBM-DTI Correlates of Verbal Intelligence: A Potential Link to Broca's area|journal=Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience|date=Apr 2012|volume=24|issue=4|pages=888–895|doi=10.1162/jocn_a_00187 |pmid=22220724}}</ref> Next, the brain must plan how to physically create the sounds necessary for speech by linking the planned speech with known sounds, or [[phonemes]]. While the location of these associations is not known, it is known that the [[supplementary motor area]] plays a key role in this step.<ref name="Bohland 2010" /><ref name=Penfield>{{cite book|last=Penfield|first=Wilder|title=Speech and Brain-Mechanism|year=1959|publisher=Atheneum}}</ref> Finally, the brain must signal for the words to actually be spoken. This is carried out by the [[premotor cortex]] and the [[motor cortex]].<ref name="Penfield" />
[[File:Human motor cortex topography.png|thumb|right|[[Motor cortex]] with muscle [[localization of function|localization]] shown]] In most cases, speech production is controlled by the left hemisphere. In a series of studies, [[Wilder Penfield]], among others, probed the brains of both right-handed (generally [[Lateralization of brain function|left-hemisphere dominant]]) and left-handed (generally [[Lateralization of brain function|right-hemisphere dominant]]) patients. They discovered that, regardless of [[handedness]], the left hemisphere was almost always the speech controlling side. However, it has been discovered that in cases of neural [[Stress (biology)|stress]] ([[hemorrhage]], [[stroke]], etc.) the right hemisphere has the ability to take control of speech functions.<ref name=Doidge>{{cite book|last=Doidge|first=Norman|title=The Brain That Changes Itself: Stories of Personal Triumph from the Frontiers of Brain Science|year=2007|publisher=Penguin Books}}</ref>
=== Comprehension === {{Main|Hearing}} Verbal Comprehension is a fairly complex process, and it is not fully understood. From various studies and experiments, it has been found that the [[superior temporal sulcus]] activates when hearing human speech, and that speech processing seems to occur within [[Wernicke's area]].<ref name="Rodd 2005" /><ref name="Penfield" />
====Auditory feedback and feedforward==== Hearing plays an important part in both speech generation and comprehension. When speaking, the person can hear their speech, and the brain uses what it hears as a [[feedback]] mechanism to fix [[speech error]]s.<ref name="Perkell 2012">{{cite journal|last=Perkell|first=Joseph|title=Movement goals and feedback and feed forward control mechanisms in speech production|journal=Journal of Neurolinguistics|date=Sep 2012|volume=25|issue=5|pages=382–407|doi=10.1016/j.jneuroling.2010.02.011|pmc=3361736}}</ref> If a single [[feedback]] correction occurs multiple times, the brain will begin to incorporate the correction to all future speech, making it a [[Feed forward (control)|feed forward]] mechanism.<ref name="Perkell 2012" /> This is apparent in some deaf people. [[Deafness]], as well as other, smaller deficiencies in hearing, can greatly affect one's ability to comprehend spoken language, as well as to speak it.<ref name="Tourville 2008">{{cite journal|last=Tourville|first=Jason|author2=Kevin Reilly |author3=Frank Guenther |title=Neural mechanisms underlying auditory feedback control of speech|journal=NeuroImage|date=1 February 2008|volume=39|issue=3|pages=1429–1443|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2007.09.054}}</ref> However, if the person loses hearing ability later in life, most can still maintain a normal level of verbal intelligence. This is thought to be because of the brain's [[Feed forward (control)|feed forward]] mechanism still helping to fix [[speech error]]s, even in the absence of [[auditory feedback]].<ref name="Perkell 2012" />
===Written language===
====Generation==== {{Main|Writing}} Generation of written language is thought to be closely related to speech generation, relying on [[Broca's area]] for early processing and on the [[inferior frontal gyrus]] for semantic processing.<ref name="Rodd 2005" /><ref name="Penfield" /> However, writing differs in two major ways. First, instead of relating the thought to sounds, the brain must relate the thought to symbols or letters, and second, the [[motor cortex]] activates a different set of muscles to write, than when speaking.<ref name="Penfield" />
====Comprehension==== {{Main|Reading (process)|l1=Reading}} Written comprehension, similar to spoken comprehension, seems to occur primarily in [[Wernicke's area]].<ref name="Penfield" /> However, instead of using the auditory system to gain language input, written comprehension relies on the visual system.
==Genetic links== [[File:Protein NRXN1 PDB 1c4r.png|thumb|right|Protein NRXN1, which is created from the NRXN1 gene]] While the capabilities of the physical structures used are large factors in determining linguistic intelligence, there have been several [[genes]] that have been linked to individual linguistic ability.<ref name="Szalontai 2013">{{cite journal|last=Szalontai|first=Adam|author2=Katalin Csiszar |title=Genetic insights into the functional elements of language|journal=Human Genetics|date=September 2013|volume=132|issue=9|pages=959–986|doi=10.1007/s00439-013-1317-0|pmid=23749164}}</ref> The [[NRXN1]] gene has been linked to general language ability, and [[mutation]]s of this gene has been shown to cause major issues to overall linguistic intelligence.<ref name="Szalontai 2013" /> The [[CNTNAP2]] gene is believed to affect [[language development]] and performance, and [[mutation]]s in this gene is thought to be involved in [[Autism spectrum|autism spectrum disorders]].<ref name="Szalontai 2013" /> [[PCDH11]] has been linked to language capacity, and it is believed to be one of the factors that accounts for the variation in linguistic intelligence.<ref name="Szalontai 2013" />
==Measurement and testing== In general, it is difficult to test for linguistic intelligence as a whole, therefore verbal intelligence is often measured instead. This is done using various types of [[verbal fluency test]]s.<ref name="Dan 2013" /><ref name="Konrad 2012" /><ref name="CC 2013">{{cite journal|last=Casals-Coll|first=M. |author2=Sanchez-Benavides |author3=Quintana |author4=Manero |author5=Rognoni |author6=Calvo |author7=Palomo |author8=Aranciva |author9=Tamayo |author10=Pena-Casanova |title=Spanish normative studies in young adults (NEURONORMA young adults project): Normative data: norms for verbal fluency tests|journal=Neurologia|date=Jan–Feb 2013|volume=28|issue=1|pages=33–40|doi=10.1016/j.nrleng.2012.02.003}}</ref>
===Verbal fluency tests=== *[[Semantics|Semantic]] Fluency Test - Subjects are asked to produce words in groups, such as animals, kitchen tools, fruits, etc. This type of test focuses on the subject's ability to generate words that have meaning to them. This test has been found to be sensitive to age.<ref name="CC 2013" /> *Formal Fluency Test - Subjects are asked to produce words given specific letter-based rules. This test has been found to be sensitive to education level.<ref name="CC 2013" /> **Initial Letter Fluency Test - A type of formal fluency test where the subject is asked to list words starting with a specific letter.<ref name="CC 2013" /> **Excluded Letter Fluency Test - A type of formal fluency test where the subject is asked to list words that do not contain a certain letter.<ref name="CC 2013" /> *[[Verb]] Fluency Test - Subjects are asked to list verbs. Subjects are then tested on their ability to use listed verbs.<ref name="CC 2013" /> *Verbal Reproduction Test - Subjects are asked to listen to a [[monologue]]. They are then asked to repeat the monologue, and the subject is scored based on the number of words and [[Lemma (morphology)|lemmas]] used from the original monologue.<ref name="FM 2012" />
===Verbal fluency in children=== In one series of tests, it was shown that when children were given verbal fluency tests, a larger portion of their [[Cerebral cortex|cortex]] activated compared to adults, as well as activation of both the left and right hemispheres. This is most likely due to the high [[Neuroplasticity|plasticity]] of newly developing brains.<ref name="Gaillard 2000">{{cite journal|last=Gaillard|first=W.D. |author2=Hertz-Pannier |author3=Mott |author4=Barnett |author5=LeBihan |author6=Theodore |title=Functional anatomy of cognitive development - fMRI of verbal fluency in children and adults|journal=Neurology|date=Jan 2000|volume=54|issue=1|pages=180–185|doi=10.1212/wnl.54.1.180}}</ref>
===Possible conflict=== Recently, a study was done showing that verbal fluency test results can differ depending on the mental focus of the subject. In this study, mental focus on physical [[speech production]] mechanisms caused speech production times to suffer, whereas mental focus on [[auditory feedback]] improved these times.<ref name="Lisman 2013">{{cite journal|last=Lisman|first=Amanda|author2=Neeraja, Sadagopan |title=Focus of attention and speech motor performance|journal=Journal of Communication Disorders|date=May–Jun 2013|volume=46|issue=3|pages=281–293|doi=10.1016/j.jcomdis.2013.02.002}}</ref>
==Disorders affecting linguistic intelligence== {{Main|Speech-language pathology}} Since linguistic intelligence is based on several complex skills, there are many disorders and injuries that can affect an individual's linguistic intelligence.
===Injuries=== Damage and injury in the brain can severely lower one's ability to communicate, and therefore lower one's linguistic intelligence. Common forms of major damage are [[strokes]], [[concussions]], [[brain tumor]]s, [[Virus|viral]]/[[bacteria]]l damage, and [[drug]]-related damage. The three major [[Language disorder|linguistic disorders]] that result from these injuries are [[aphasia]], [[alexia (condition)|alexia]], and [[agraphia]].<ref name="Penfield" /> [[Aphasia]] is the inability to speak, and can be caused by damage to [[Broca's area]] or the [[motor cortex]].<ref name="Penfield" /> Alexia is the inability to read, which can arise from damage to [[Wernicke's area]], among other places.<ref name="Penfield" /> [[Agraphia]] is the inability to write which can also arise from damage to [[Broca's area]] or the [[motor cortex]].<ref name="Penfield" /> In addition, damage to large areas of the brain can result in any combinations of these disorders, as well as a loss of other abilities.<ref name="Penfield" />
===Pure language disorders=== There are several disorders that primarily affect only language skills. Three major pure language disorders are [[Developmental verbal dyspraxia]], [[specific language impairment]], and [[stuttering]].<ref name="Szalontai 2013" /> [[Developmental verbal dyspraxia]] (DVD) is a disorder where children have errors in consonant and vowel production.<ref name="Szalontai 2013" /> [[Specific language impairment]] (SLI) is a disorder where the patient has a lack of [[language acquisition]] skills, despite a seemingly normal [[intelligence]] level in other areas.<ref name="Szalontai 2013" /> [[Stuttering]] is a fairly common disorder where speech flow is interrupted by involuntary repetitions of [[syllable]]s.<ref name="Szalontai 2013" />
===Other disorders affecting language=== Some disorders cause a wide array of effects, and language impairment is merely one of many possible [[symptom]]s. The two major disorders of this type are [[autism spectrum|autism spectrum disorder]] and [[epilepsy]].<ref name="Szalontai 2013" /> [[Autism]] and other [[autism spectrum|autism spectrum disorders]] (ASD) are disorders in which the patient suffers from decreased [[social skills]] and lowered [[Cognitive flexibility|mental flexibility]]. As a result, many patients suffering from ASDs also have language problems, arising from both the lack of social interaction and lowered mental flexibility.<ref name="Szalontai 2013" /> [[Epilepsy]] is a disorder where electrical malfunctions or mis-communications in the brain cause [[Epileptic seizure|seizures]], leading to muscle [[spasm]]s and activation of other organs and systems of the body. Over time, epilepsy can lead to cognitive and behavioral decay. This mental decay can eventually lead to a loss of language and communication skills.<ref name="Szalontai 2013" />

[[Image:Tampereen tuomikirkko kesä 2004 IMG 2328.JPG|thumb|270px|right|National Romantic style in [[Finland]] — [[Tampere Cathedral]].]] The '''National Romantic style''' was a [[Nordic countries|Nordic]] architectural style that was part of the [[Romantic nationalism|National Romantic movement]] during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. It is often considered to be a form of [[Art Nouveau]].
==History== The National Romantic style spread across [[Finland]]; the Scandinavian countries of [[Denmark]], [[Norway]], and [[Sweden]]; the Baltic countries of [[Estonia]] and [[Latvia]], as well as [[Russia]] (mainly [[Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]]). Unlike much nostalgic [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival style]] architecture elsewhere, National Romantic architecture expressed progressive social and political ideals, through reformed domestic architecture.<ref>Barbara Miller Lane, ''National Romanticism and Modern Architecture in Germany and the Scandinavian Countries'' (New York: Cambridge University Press), 2000:10.</ref>
Designers turned to early [[medieval architecture]] and even prehistoric precedents to construct a style appropriate to the perceived character of a people. The style can be seen as a reaction to industrialism and an expression of the same "Dream of the North" nationalism that gave impetus to renewed interest in the [[edda]]s and [[saga]]s.

'''Neo-Fauvism''' was a poetic style of painting from the mid-1920s proposed as a challenge to [[Surrealism]].<ref name=grant>Grant, Kim. ''Surrealism and the Visual Arts: Theory and Reception'', [http://www.cambridge.org/aus/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521836555&ss=exc Introduction]. Cambridge University Press 2005. {{ISBN|978-0-521-83655-5}}, {{ISBN|0-521-83655-7}}.</ref>
The magazine ''Cahiers d'Art'' was launched in 1926 and its writers mounted a challenge to the [[Surrealism|Surrealist]] practice of [[Surrealist automatism|automatism]] by seeing it not in terms of [[Unconscious mind|unconscious]] expression, but as another development of traditional artistry. They identified a group of artists as the exponents of this and termed them Neo-Fauves.<ref name=grant/>
Although these artists were later mostly forgotten, the movement had an effect of disillusioning the Surrealist group with the technique of graphic automatism as a revolutionary means of by-passing conventional aesthetics, ideology and commercialism.<ref name=grant/>
Neo-Fauvism has been seen as the last trend within painting that could be marketed as a coherent style.<ref name=GoetheInsitut>[http://www.goethe.de/kue/bku/thm/ein/en178614.htm Goethe-Institut], retrieved 10 June 2008. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070822212258/http://www.goethe.de/kue/bku/thm/ein/en178614.htm |date=August 22, 2007 }}</ref>

'''Northwest Nazarene University''' ('''NNU''') is a private [[Christian]] [[liberal arts college]] located in [[Nampa, Idaho|Nampa]], [[Idaho]], U.S.
==History== {| class=wikitable align="left" style="margin-right:1.6em" |+Presidents |- | || [[Fred J. Shields]] || 1917–1919 |- |1. || [[H. Orton Wiley]] || 1919–1926 |- |2. || [[Joseph G. Morrison]] || 1926–1927 |- |3. || [[Russell V. DeLong]] || 1927–1932 |- |4. || R. Eugene Gilmore || 1932–1935 |- |5. || [[Russell V. DeLong]] || 1935–1942 |- |6. || L.T. Corlett || 1942–1952 |- |7. || [[John E. Riley]] || 1952–1973 |- |8. || [[Kenneth H. Pearsall]] || 1973–1983 |- |9. || [[A. Gordon Wetmore]] || 1983–1992 |- |10. || Leon Doane || 1992–1993 |- |11. || Richard A. Hagood || 1993–2008 |- |12. || David Alexander || 2008–2015 |- |13. || Joel Pearsall || 2015–Present |} Eugene Emerson organized a combination [[grade school]] and [[Bible school]] in 1913 as Idaho Holiness School.<ref>Riley, John E. From Sagebrush to Ivy: The story of Northwest Nazarene College. Pacific Press, Nampa, Idaho, 1988.</ref><ref name="Ingersol">{{cite paper |first = Stan |last = Ingersol |author = |authorlink = |title = Why These Schools? Historical Perspectives on Nazarene Higher Education |version = |publisher = |url = http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/Why%20These%20Schools%20%20Historical%20Perspectives%20on%20Nazarene%20Higher%20Education.pdf |format = [[PDF]] |accessdate = 2008-07-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080624230418/http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/Why%20These%20Schools%20%20Historical%20Perspectives%20on%20Nazarene%20Higher%20Education.pdf |archivedate = 2008-06-24 |df = }}</ref> It was renamed twice in 1916, first to Northwest Holiness College and then to Northwest Nazarene College,<ref>{{cite book | last = Raser | first = Harold E. |editor=Thomas C. Hunt |editor2=James C. Carper |chapter=Church of the Nazarene Universities, Colleges, and Religious Seminaries | title = Religious Higher Education in the United States | publisher = Taylor & Francis | year = 1996 | location = | url = https://books.google.com/?id=lxr_PID7o2IC&printsec=frontcover&q | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-8153-1636-4 | page = 549 }}</ref> and then became a [[liberal arts college]] in 1917 with degree-granting authority from the Idaho state Board of Education. While the first president elected for the college in 1916 was [[H. Orton Wiley]] of [[Pasadena University]], [[Fred J. Shields]] would fill in as acting president before leaving for the [[Eastern Nazarene College]] in 1919, while Wiley finished his [[postgraduate education|graduate work]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Cameron | first = James R. | authorlink = James R. Cameron | title = Eastern Nazarene College—The First Fifty Years, 1900-1950 | publisher = Nazarene Publishing House | year = 1968 | location = Kansas City | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = | pages = 127, 142–143}}</ref> Under [[Russell V. DeLong]], Northwest Nazarene College (NNC) received [[educational accreditation]],<ref name="NWCCU">{{Cite web |url=http://www.nwccu.org/Directory%20of%20Inst/State%20Map/Idaho/Idaho.htm |title=NWCCU: Idaho schools |access-date=2008-04-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080703165048/http://www.nwccu.org/Directory%20of%20Inst/State%20Map/Idaho/Idaho.htm |archive-date=2008-07-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> as a two-year school in 1931<ref name="policy">[http://www.nnu.edu/fileadmin/Content/FinAffairs/Sherrys/Forms/Administrative_Policy_Manual_01.pdf NNU Administrative Policy Manual]</ref> and then received accreditation as a four-year school in 1937,<ref name="policy"/> making it the first accredited college affiliated with the [[Church of the Nazarene]].<ref>The next Nazarene college to be accredited wasn't until 6 years later, when [[Eastern Nazarene]] was accredited by [[New England Association of Schools and Colleges|NEASC]] in 1943. Northwest had the ''authority to grant degrees'' from the State of Idaho before 1930, but ENC didn't have the authority to grant degrees in the [[Commonwealth of Massachusetts]] ''until'' 1930. Before 1930, ENC students actually received degrees from NNU. See James R. Cameron, ''Eastern Nazarene College—The First Fifty Years, 1900-1950'', Nazarene Publishing House (1968), 163.</ref> Under Presidents [[John E. Riley]] and [[Kenneth H. Pearsall]] in the 1960s and 1970s, [[master's degree]] programs were added.<ref name="NNU History">{{Cite web |url=http://www.nnu.edu/2966 |title=NNU History |access-date=2007-06-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070608123055/http://www.nnu.edu/2966/ |archive-date=2007-06-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.nnu.edu/offices/office-of-the-president/presidents-messages/fall-2008-presidents-dinner-message/ Fall 2008 President's Dinner at NNU] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809150945/http://www.nnu.edu/offices/office-of-the-president/presidents-messages/fall-2008-presidents-dinner-message/ |date=2009-08-09 }}</ref> It was renamed as Northwest Nazarene University (NNU) in 1999.
==Mission== The mission of Northwest Nazarene University is the transformation of the whole person. Centered in Jesus Christ, the NNU education instills habits of heart, soul, mind and strength to enable each student to become God's creative and redemptive agent in the world.<ref>{{cite web|title=Northwest Nazarene University: Mission, Values, & Vision|url=http://www.nnu.edu/about/mission-values-vision/|work=Northwest Nazarene University website|access-date=2012-01-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215013324/http://www.nnu.edu/about/mission-values-vision/|archive-date=2012-02-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
==Affiliations== As one of eight U.S. [[liberal arts college]]s<ref>{{cite paper |first = Price |last = J. Matthew |author = |authorlink = |title = Liberal Arts and the Priorities of Nazarene Higher Education |version = |publisher = |url = http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/didache_2_1_Price.pdf |format = [[PDF]] |accessdate = 2008-07-10 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080627054254/http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/didache_2_1_Price.pdf |archivedate = 2008-06-27 |df = }} Nazarene [[higher education]] is based on the [[liberal arts]] model. Eastern Nazarene is the only Nazarene institution to retain the "college" moniker, although no Nazarene school fits the [http://educationusa.state.gov/graduate/about/types.htm standard national definition] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516215315/http://educationusa.state.gov/graduate/about/types.htm |date=2008-05-16 }} of a "research university".</ref> affiliated with the [[Church of the Nazarene]],<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title =Nazarene Educational Regions| work =| publisher =| url =http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/educregions.pdf| format =PDF| doi =| accessdate =2008-07-10| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20080624230421/http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/educregions.pdf| archivedate =2008-06-24| df =}} See [[Church of the Nazarene#Organization|Church of the Nazarene: Organization]] for more information on regions.</ref> the college receives financial backing from the Nazarene churches on its region; part of each church budget is paid into a fund for its regional school. Each college is also bound by a [[gentlemen's agreement]] not to actively recruit outside its respective educational region.<ref>{{cite book| last =| first =| authorlink =| title =Guidelines and Handbook for Educational Institutions of the Church of the Nazarene| publisher =Church of the Nazarene International Board of Education| year =1997| location =| url =http://www.nazarene.org/files/docs/guide.pdf| doi =| id =| isbn =| page =14| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20091010012525/http://www.nazarene.org/files/docs/guide.pdf| archivedate =2009-10-10| df =}}</ref> NNU is the college for the Northwest Region of the United States, which comprises the Alaska, Washington Pacific, Oregon Pacific, Northwest, Intermountain, Rocky Mountain, and Colorado districts, which include [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[Oregon]], [[Idaho]], [[Montana]], [[Wyoming]], [[Colorado]], [[Alaska]], and parts of [[Nevada]] and [[Utah]].<ref>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| title =Northwest Educational Region| work =| publisher =| url =http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/NorthwestUSAregiondistricts.pdf| format =PDF| doi =| accessdate =2008-07-10| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20080911032012/http://media.premierstudios.com/nazarene/docs/NorthwestUSAregiondistricts.pdf| archivedate =2008-09-11| df =}} [[Eastern Nazarene College|ENC]] and NNU are the only Nazarene schools to remain true to their regional names.</ref> NNU is also a member of the [[Council for Christian Colleges and Universities]] (CCCU).<ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = CCCU Members | work = | publisher = | url = http://www.cccu.org/about/members.asp | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-07-10 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080705064221/http://www.cccu.org/about/members.asp <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-07-05}}</ref> NNU has been accredited by the [[Northwest Commission on Colleges and Universities]] (NWCCU) since 1930, making it the first Nazarene school to achieve an accredited status.<ref name="NWCCU"/>
==Academics== Northwest Nazarene University has two colleges: the College of Arts and Sciences and the College of Adult and Graduate Studies. NNU offers over 60 baccalaureate degree programs, 11 master's degree programs, and a Ph.D. degree program. In addition to its 90-acre campus located in Nampa, Idaho, the University offers extensive online degree programs and has branch campuses in Boise, Twin Falls, and Idaho Falls. Founded in 1913, the university now serves over 1300 undergraduate and 700 graduate students, more than 6000 online and continuing education students, and 2300 high school concurrent credit students. NNU is accredited by the Northwest Commission on Colleges and Universities, and has been consistently rated by U.S. News & World Report as one of the top masters-level universities in the west as well as by the Princeton Review's "Book of The Best Western Colleges."
==Student life== NNU is a [[co-educational]] college. According to [[InsideHigherEd]] and the [[Council for Christian Colleges and Universities]], [[Black people|black student]] enrollment at NNU is one percent or less of the entire student population.<ref>[http://www.insidehighered.com/news/2008/08/15/christian InsideHigherEd.com: "Christian Colleges Grow More Diverse". August 15, 2008.]</ref>
===Athletics=== {{main|Northwest Nazarene Nighthawks}} NNU participates in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]'s [[Great Northwest Athletic Conference]] at the [[NCAA Division II]] level in 8 sports: [[basketball]], [[baseball]], [[cross country running]], [[golf]], [[softball]], [[soccer]], [[track and field]], and [[volleyball]].<ref>[http://www.nnusports.com/ NNU Sports]</ref> NNU added tennis as a club team in the Fall of 2013. Along with the [[Eastern Nazarene College]], it is one of only two Nazarene colleges to compete in the NCAA; the other six compete in the [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]]. NNU's [[athletic moniker]] is the "[[Nighthawk]]s" (as of October 16, 2017; the nickname was previously the Crusader) and colors are [[red]] and [[black]]. The school’s main rival is [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] [[College of Idaho]], located a short distance to the west in [[Caldwell, Idaho]].
==Notable persons==<!--- must be paragraph format per WP:UNIGUIDE ---> Notable graduates include [[Lori Otter]] First Lady of the State of Idaho. [[Kent R. Hill]], the former administrator for [[USAID]]'s Bureau for Global Health and former president of the [[Eastern Nazarene College]] (1992-2001), [[Richard Hieb]], NASA astronaut, author [[Donna Fletcher Crow]], and [[Michael Lodahl]] and [[Thomas Jay Oord]], noted [[Church of the Nazarene|Nazarene]] [[theologian]]s. Oord is current faculty at his [[alma mater]]. A notable non-graduate alumna is [[Mildred Bangs Wynkoop]], another noted Nazarene theologian. Notable former faculty members include [[Fred J. Shields]], [[H. Orton Wiley]], and [[Olive Winchester]].
